No. 79 West Yingze Street Taiyuan 030024 China TiO2 is widely used in oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) reaction because of its low cost, reducibility and nontoxicity, but pure TiO2 has poor activity on methane activation. Density functional theory with an additional Hubbard-like parameter (DFT + U) was used to research OCM reaction on Ir/TiO2(001), Pt/TiO2(001) and Mn/TiO2(001) catalysts to explore catalysts with high activity and C2 hydrocarbon selectivity. The results indicate that Ir, Pt and Mn doping can significantly improve the activity of lattice oxygen and reduce the activation energy of methane dissociation. Additionally, the evolution of oxygen species on Ir/TiO2(001) Pt/TiO2(001) and Mn/TiO2(001) catalysts show that the lattice oxygen species and peroxide species have the strongest activity to activate methane. However, the superoxide species has the worst activity. Furthermore, the formation paths of ethane and ethylene were researched on Ir/TiO2(001), Pt/TiO2(001) and Mn/TiO2(001) surfaces. And we expect that Ir/TiO2(001) is effective for catalyzing OCM reaction. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) Density functional theory (DFT) TiO2 Catalytic activity Activation oxygen species Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction As important sources of clean fossil energy, natural gas and shale gas are attracting increasing attention. Methane is essential component of natural gas and shale gas. Developing the procedure of converting methane into value-added products has great economic and sustainable significance [1–3]. Catalytic conversion of methane via OCM is a critical choice for industry to meet the global requirements for ethylene [4,5]. OCM is a process in which methane is directly converted into C2 hydrocarbons under condition of oxygen [6]. In the process of OCM reaction, gas phase oxygen is conducive to occur the complete oxidation leading to product CO and CO2, which is more favorable than OCM reaction in thermodynamics, limiting the selectivity of the required hydrocarbon products [7]. As a results, the C2 yield of OCM is limited to less than 30 % economically feasible, and industrial application has not realized [8–11]. In order to meet these challenges, a technology named chemical looping oxidative coupling of methane (CLOCM) has been studied. CLOCM takes advantage of crystal lattice oxygen of reducible metal oxide as the oxygen source, which leads to the absence of gaseous oxygen in the reaction system, eliminates unwanted gas-phase oxidation reaction, and may improve the upper limit of C2+ yield achieved by OCM [12–15]. At present, TiO2, as a reducible metal oxide, has been widely studied because of its low cost, high specific surface area and nontoxicity [16–18]. Recently, the pure TiO2 nanoparticles has been found to exhibit excellent catalytic propane dehydrogenation reaction performance, and the surface lattice oxygen can activate reducing propane [19]. However, pure TiO2 has poor activity on methane activation [20,21]. Doping transition metal into TiO2 nanowires can modify the catalytic activity of TiO2 [22]. Fung et al.[20] showed that single transition metal atoms on TiO2 can activate the C-H bond of methane. Pt has the ability to selectively activate C-H bond in methane [23]. The introduction of Pt single atom on Cu(111) surface promotes the activation of C-H bond and reduces energy barrier of C2 formation [24]. Iridium (Ir) has an unusual ability to activate the C-H bond of hydrocarbons [25]. The existence of low-coordination surface can strongly enhance the reactivity of Ir to alkane activation [26,27]. In addition, both experimental and theoretical studies found that the (001) facet of anatase TiO2 have high reactivity. TiO2(001) surface is mainly exposed to coordination unsaturated atoms, such as 5-coordinated Ti (Ti5c) atom and 2-coordinated O (O2c) atom, which tend to bind with external species [28,29]. Significantly, Yang and co-works [30,31] have synthesized anatase TiO2 single crystals with (001) plane accounting for 47 % and 90 % respectively. During OCM reaction, the active oxygen species on the surface of metal oxide catalysts are generally considered to the active sites involved in the activation methane. Surface oxygen species mainly consist of lattice oxygen (O2-), superoxide species (O2 -), peroxide species (O2 2-) [32]. Clarifying the role of different surface oxygen species in OCM reaction has great guiding significance of the design for efficient OCM catalyst. In this work, we will focus on doping single metal atom Ir and Pt on the surface of anatase TiO2(001) to improve the activity of methane conversion, and control the selective activation of methane to CH x (x = 2, 3) species. In addition, the complete cycle of OCM reaction on Ir/TiO2(001) and Pt/TiO2(001) surfaces will be studied to explore the role of different oxygen species. Mn-doped TiO2 nanowire catalyst exhibited high catalytic performance [33]. Hence, using Mn as a reference dopant should be required for the better discussion of our demonstration. For this purpose, an extensive DFT + U study has been performed to study the mechanism of OCM reaction on Ir/TiO2(001), Pt/TiO2(001) and Mn/TiO2(001) surfaces. 2 Calculation method and model The Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) [34–36] was employed for all of the periodic plane-wave density functional theory (DFT) [37,38] calculations. Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional in the generalized gradient approximation with a Hubbard-like parameter (GGA + U) was used as the exchange-correlation potential [39,40]. The U value of Ti and Mn was determined as 4 eV [41,42]. The Monk-horst-Pack k-points [43] of 2 × 3 × 1 for TiO2(001) and M/TiO2(110) (M=Ir, Pt and Mn) surfaces was applied. The plane wave cutoff energy was set as 400 eV. The convergence of states near the Fermi level was improved by SIGMA= 0.1 eV. The convergence criterion of geometry optimization on the force of each atom and energy were less than 0.03 eV/Å and 1 × 10−5 eV respectively. The climbing-image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) [44,45] and the dimer methods [46] were used for Transition states (TSs) searched. The saddle point between the known reactants and products was obtained using the CI-NEB method [47,48]. The forces of the TSs structure optimization by the dimer approach on all atoms were less than 0.05 eV/Å [49]. The adsorption energies (E ads) of reaction molecules adsorbed on TiO2(001) and M/TiO2(001) (M=Ir and Pt) surfaces are calculated using the equation: (1) E a d s = E a d s o r b a t e / s u b s t r a t e − E a d s o r b a t e − E s u b s t r a t e where E adsorbate /substrate, E adsorbate and E substrate are the total energies of the adsorption system, free adsorbate and substrate, respectively. The activation energy (E a) and the reaction energy (ΔE) are calculated by the formulas as follows: (2) E a = E T S − E I S (3) Δ E = E F S − E I S where E IS, E TS and E FS are the total energies of the reactant, the TSs and the product, respectively. The smaller the E a, the more advantages the reaction will have. The TiO2(001) surface was modeled by a p(2 ×3) slab with 12 at. layers including 4 O-Ti-O repeat units, and adding 15 Å vacuum region in the vertical direction to separate the slabs [50]. In the process of geometry optimization, the lowest 6 layers were kept fixed, and the top 6 layers and species were relaxed. For M/TiO2(001) surfaces, one of the surface Ti atoms was substituted by a M (M=Ir, Pt and Mn) atom. Because the activation energy of the rate determination step of generating ethane is higher than that of generating ethylene, the main C2 product on the Mn/TiO2(001) surface is ethylene. 3.3 Effect of different oxygen species on OCM reaction Using lattice oxygen in metal oxide as the oxygen source of OCM reaction can eliminate unnecessary gas-phase reaction, potentially improving the C2+ yield [62,63]. In the OCM reaction process, oxygen species presents different forms in different stages of the reaction and play different roles in the catalytic reaction process. The consumption of lattice oxygen and the recycling of surface oxygen species are important to the catalytic performance and service life of OCM catalyst. Therefore, in this section, the evolution of the surface oxygen species on Ir/TiO2(001), Pt/TiO2(001) and Mn/TiO2(001) surfaces. According to different active oxygen sources, the reaction process can be roughly divided into two stages. In the first stage, CH4 is activated by lattice oxygen and then transformed into C2 hydrocarbon products and H2O, leaving oxygen vacancy (Ov) on the catalyst surface. In the second stage, Ov is filled with gaseous O2 to further oxidize CH4 and restores the surface [64,65]. 3.3.1 Evolution of active oxygen species on the Ir/TiO2(001) surface On the Ir/TiO2(001) surface, the CH4 oxidation reaction cycle includes seven elementary reaction steps, as illustrated in Scheme 1. (1) CH4 is activated at the O2c site, which involves the energy barrier of 0.47 eV and is exothermic by 1.02 eV. After the first reaction step, an OH group is formed on the surface. Subsequently, (2) a second CH4 is activated at the OH species to produce a H2O on the surface. The activation energy of this reaction is 0.67 eV and endothermic is 0.33 eV. (3) The H2O desorbs from the Ir/TiO2(001) surface with a desorption energy of 1.29 eV and an Ov is formed on the surface. (4) Gaseous O2 is adsorbed at the Ov with a tremendous adsorption energy of − 7.51 eV, and the O-O bond length elongates significantly from 1.234 to 1.419 Å. A peroxide O2 2- species is generated on the surface [66]. (5) Notably, the adsorbed O2 2- activate a third CH4 with a very low energy barrier of 0.35 eV. Meanwhile, the O-O bond in O2 2- breaks, one O atom becomes lattice oxygen, and another O atom forms OH with dissociated H atom, which is adsorbed at the adjacent Ti atom. (6) Then for the C-H bond dissociation of the fourth CH4 in the whole reaction cycle, the OH species break the C-H bond with an activation energy of 0.73 eV. Soon afterwards, one H2O molecule forms on the Ir/TiO2(001) surface. (7) In the last step of the cycle, the H2O molecule desorbs into gas phase with a desorption energy of 0.81 eV and the surface is recovered. 3.3.2 Evolution of active oxygen species on the Pt/TiO2(001) surface On the Pt/TiO2(001) surface, four steps from step (1) CH4 is activated to step (4) O2 is adsorbed at the Ov, are the same as that on the Ir/TiO2(001) surface, but the activation energies are different. After gas phase O2 supplement Ov, the O-O bond length elongates to 1.275 Å, and a superoxide O2 - species is generated on the surface. (5) The adsorbed O2 - activate a third CH4 with a high energy barrier of 1.54 eV. After that, an OOH species is formed on the Pt/TiO2(001) surface. (6) The OOH species break the C-H bond dissociation of the fourth CH4 with an energy barrier of 2.13 eV. Then one H2O is formed and transferred to the adjacent Ti atom. (7) In the last step of the cycle, the H2O molecule desorbs from the Pt/TiO2(001) surface, the desorption energy is 1.11 eV and the surface is recovered. 3.3.3 Evolution of active oxygen species on the Mn/TiO2(001) surface On the Mn/TiO2(001) surface, four steps from step (1) CH4 is activated to step (4) O2 is adsorbed at the Ov, are the same as that on Ir/TiO2(001) and Pt/TiO2(001) surfaces, but the activation energies are different. (Fig. S3.) After gas phase O2 supplement Ov, the O-O bond length elongates to 1.320 Å, and a superoxide O2 - species is generated on the surface. (5) The adsorbed O2 - activate a third CH4 with a high energy barrier of 1.67 eV. After that, an OOH species is formed on the Mn/TiO2(001) surface. (6) The OOH species break the C-H bond dissociation of the fourth CH4 with an energy barrier of 0.78 eV. Then one H2O is formed and transferred to the adjacent Ti atom. (7) In the last step of the cycle, the H2O molecule desorbs from the Mn/TiO2(001) surface, the desorption energy is 0.76 eV and the surface is recovered. 3.3.4 Effect of different active oxygen species According to the above calculation results, the types of oxygen species existing in the OCM reaction on the Ir/TiO2(001) surface are O2-, OH and O2 2-, and the corresponding methane dissociation activation energy under the effect of these oxygen species are 0.47, 0.67 and 0.35 eV, respectively. The activity of the three oxygen species is higher than that of the lattice oxygen on the undoped TiO2(001) surface. The oxygen species in OCM reaction on the Pt/TiO2(001) surface are O2-, OH, O2 -and HO2 -. Among them, O2-and OH are the main active oxygen species to activate methane, and the activation energies are 0.19 and 0.72 eV, respectively. Therefore, O2- has better catalytic activity for methane than OH on the Pt/TiO2(001) surface. O2 - accepts an H atom to form HO2 - species which shows no activity to activate methane, but decompose into O and OH during the reaction. The oxygen species in OCM reaction on the Mn/TiO2(001) surface are O2-, OH, O2 -and HO2 -. Among them, O2-and HO2 - are the main active oxygen species to activate methane, and the activation energies are 0.36 and 0.78 eV, respectively. Therefore, O2- has better catalytic activity for methane than HO2 - on the Mn/TiO2(001) surface. Then we also studied the formation of dissociated atomic oxygen and its influence of methane activation on Ir/TiO2(001) and Pt/TiO2(001) surfaces. As shown in Fig. S4 and S5, on Ir/TiO2(001) and Pt/TiO2(001) surfaces, the activation energies of dissociation O2 to generate dissociated atomic oxygen are 1.18 and 2.73 eV respectively. We expect that doped Ir/TiO2(001) is effective for catalyzing OCM reaction. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, we have systematically studied the reaction of OCM on Ir/TiO2(001), Pt/TiO2(001) and Mn/TiO2(001) surfaces by using the DFT method. We found that the initial dissociation activation energies of methane on Ir/TiO2(001) (0.47 eV), Pt/TiO2(001) (0.19 eV) and Mn/TiO2(001) (0.36 eV) surfaces are significantly lower than that on the pure TiO2(001) (1.02 eV) surface, which indicates that the doping of Ir, Pt and Mn can improve the methane conversion activity. For the generation of C2 hydrocarbon, the main C2 product is ethane on doped Ir/TiO2(001) and Pt/TiO2(001), and the generation paths are the same, both CH4→CH3→C2H6. However, the rate determining step are different, namely CH4→CH3 +H (0.47 eV) and 2CH3→C2H6 (0.24 eV). The main C2 product is ethylene on doped Mn/TiO2(001), the generation path is CH4→CH3→CH2→C2H4. The rate determination step is CH3 dissociation reaction, and its energy barrier is 0.51 eV. In contrast, Pt/TiO2(001) surface exhibit relative high activity for the formation of C2 hydrocarbon. Furthermore, we also studied CH4 oxidation by different surface oxygen species, and put forward the evolution of active oxygen species OCM reaction on doped Ir/TiO2(001), Pt/TiO2(001) and Mn/TiO2(001) surfaces. coredata.dc:description: TiO2 is widely used in oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) reaction because of its low cost, reducibility and nontoxicity, but pure TiO2 has poor activity on methane activation. Density functional theory with an additional Hubbard-like parameter (DFT + U) was used to research OCM reaction on Ir/TiO2(001), Pt/TiO2(001) and Mn/TiO2(001) catalysts to explore catalysts with high activity and C2 hydrocarbon selectivity. The results indicate that Ir, Pt and Mn doping can significantly improve the activity of lattice oxygen and reduce the activation energy of methane dissociation. Additionally, the evolution of oxygen species on Ir/TiO2(001) Pt/TiO2(001) and Mn/TiO2(001) catalysts show that the lattice oxygen species and peroxide species have the strongest activity to activate methane. However, the superoxide species has the worst activity. Furthermore, the formation paths of ethane and ethylene were researched on Ir/TiO2(001), Pt/TiO2(001) and Mn/TiO2(001) surfaces. And we expect that Ir/TiO2(001) is effective for catalyzing OCM reaction.
